Description.val:
CHEMICAL & BIOLOGICAL DEFENSE PROGRAM (INSTALLATION REQUIREMENTS):
Public Law 103-160, Section 1703 created a Joint Service Chemical and Biological Defense Program (CBDP) to address ever growing threats from the aggressive proliferation of chemical and biological weapons. Joint CBDP funds the development and procurement of Chemical and Biological Defense (CBD) Equipment to enhance the warfighter's ability to survive and complete their mission in a chemical biological contaminated environment. The Navy is responsible for the associated installation/integration and sustainment funds only. The Navy's requirement for Joint Biological Point Detection System (JBPDS), Improved Point Detection System/Lifecycle Replacement (IPDS/LR), Joint Biological Agent Identification and Diagnostic System (JBAIDS), Next Generation Chemical Detection (NGDS) System, Enhanced Maritime Biological Detection (EMBD) system and Dismounted Reconnaissance Sets, and Outfits (DRSKO) has been validated by CNO in associated Joint Operational Requirements Documents and/or Capability Production Documents.

Installation of Equipment
Funding is for installation of equipment including Fleet Modernization Program installations, installation of training equipment and installation of equipment in other shore facilities. Procurement of equipment is funded by the Joint
Service CBDP.

Detector installation costs can vary significantly, even within ship class,  depending  on installation location (East coast, West coast, OCONUS, etc.), if installation accomplished pier side or in a ship yard (i.e. availability type during which installation actually occurs), ship as built and as found conditions, and installation growth work (i.e. unplanned/unexpected work) driven by as found conditions.

[P3A / IPDS/LR]: The IPDS/LR (formerly SEACADS/IPDS) will improve the existing shipboard point detection system for detecting and identifying chemical nerve and blister agent contamination presence. Inventory objective for shipboard installations is 130.

[P3A - 2 / JBAIDS]: The JBAIDS will provide U.S. operating forces with a biological organism identification and diagnostic device that will identify and quantify biological organisms of operational concern and other pathogens of clinical significance for confirmatory and prognostic purposes. Inventory objective for shipboard JBAIDS installations is 23 and Refrigeration installations is 17.

[P3A - 4 / JBPDS BLK 1]: The JBPDS Block I will provide the Navy with automated, knowledge-based capability to detect and identify biological warfare agents in less than 20 minutes. The inventory objective for shipboard installations is 78.

[P3A - 5 / NGCD]: The Next Generation Chemical Detector (NGCD) is a technology replacement for the IPDS and IPDS-LR systems. The inventory objective for shipboard installations is 183.

[P3A - 7 / IPDS-LR Heater]: The IPDS-LR Heater Upgrade provides the ability for IPDS-LR to function in various extreme environmental conditions that may cause system degradation and ultimately failure. This is a new, emergent requirement to ensure automated chemical agent detection is operationally available. The equipment development and procurement for this upgrade is funded out of the Joint Service CBDP Budget and is expected to be provided to Navy by mid FY19. The Navy is required to fund the integration and installation. Inventory objective for shipboard installations is 77.

[P3A - 8 / CW001 CHEMICAL WARFARE PROGRAM DRSKO STOWAGE]: The CBRN Dismounted Reconnaissance Sets, Kits, and Outfits (DRSKO) consists of portable, commercial and government off-the-shelf equipment which provides Visit Board Search and Seizure (VBSS) forces with the capability to detect or deny the presence of Weapons of Mass Destruction (WMD) in support of WMD Interdiction (WMD-I) missions. This installation will install shelving and provide controlled access to support proper stowage of the Joint developed CBRN DRSKO system. The inventory objective for shipboard installations is 4.

[P3A - 9 / CW001 CHEMICAL WARFARE PROGRAM EMBD UPGRADE KIT]: OPNAVINST 3400.10G articulates U.S. Navy Chemical, Biological and Radiological Defense (CBRD) policy and establishes functional responsibilities to ensure the highest level of the Fleet readiness and warfighting sustainability in a CBR environment. The Enhanced Maritime Biological Detection (EMBD) kit is intended as a lifecycle replacement for the JBPDS system, and will include improved detection and identification capabilities. The equipment procurement is funded out of the Joint Service Chemical Biological Defense Program Budget. The inventory objective for shipboard installations is 128.

Name.@footnote: IPDS-LR plan - The procurement costs are specifically referring to Installation and Design Service Allocation (DSA) costs as there are no equipment procurement costs with any detector system installed. DSA costs are for government engineering oversight/support in preparation for ship installation and ship class planning yards for engineering services which include ship check, development and approval of ship installation drawings (SIDs), Ship Selected Record changes, Bill of Material (BOM), onsite planning yard engineering support during installation to answer liaison action record (LARs), and other engineering services depending on the planning yard. DSA costs are generally funded up to one year prior to planned installation due to drawing development lead time and installation preparation efforts. These costs are ship specific since drawings are developed for each ship, not class of ship, excluding IPDS-LR for DDG Class ships which are class-wide drawings.  - FY19 installations total seven (7) ships to include two (2) LSD-41 Class ships at $220K each, one (1) LSD-49 Class ships at $225K each, and four (4) CG-47 Class ships at $239K each. Total installation costs for FY19 is $1,631K plus $685K for DSA costs.  - FY20 installations total six (6) ships to include one (1) LDS-49 Class at $225K and five (5) CG-47 Class ships at $225K each. Total installation costs for IPDS-LR in FY20 is $1,350K plus $231K for DSA costs.  - FY21 installations total two (2) ships to include two (2) CG-47 Class at $230K each.  Total installation costs for IPDS-LR in FY21 is $460K plus $121K for DSA costs.

Description.val:
OPNAVINST 3400.10G articulates U.S. Navy Chemical, Biological and Radiological Defense (CBRD) policy and establishes functional responsibilities to ensure the highest level of the Fleet readiness and warfighting sustainability in a CBR environment. CBRD Improved Point Detection System/Lifecycle Replacement (IPDS/LR) provides shipboard point detection system for detecting and identifying nerve and blister agent contamination presence. The equipment procurement is funded out of the Joint Service Chemical Biological Defense Program Budget.

[IPDS/LR] Remarks: A total of one hundred and sixteen (116) completed. LSD-47 installation was started in FY18, but had to be halted awaiting offload of ammunition. The installation was completed third quarter FY19. Planned installation start for four (4) CG Class ships was delayed from 4th quarter FY19 to second quarter FY20 (1 each), third quarter FY20 (1 each), and fourth quarter FY20 (2 each) to better align with ship availability.  Three (3) of the delayed ships are in the middle of complex overhauls, so is more ideal to wait until the end of the ship availability to complete installation since more ship services will be back on-line. Planned installations have increased from 127 at the FY 2020 President's Budget request to 130. At the concurrence of OPNAV and USFFC, removed the two (2) previously planned installations onboard LCS-2 and LCS-4 since those hulls were recently changed to training assets and to conserve IPDS-LR for SCN ships. Added three (3) CG-47 Class ships back into the schedule to perform shock qualified installation of IPDS-LR. At the concurrence of OPNAV and USFFC, added LCS-1 and LCS-3 to the plan to remove IPDS-LR to reallocate the systems for new ship construction.

Name.@footnote: There are no equipment procurement costs with any detector system installed. The Design Service Allocation (DSA) costs are for government engineering oversight/support in preparation for ship installation and ship class planning yards for engineering services which include ship check, development and approval of ship installation drawings (SIDs), Ship Selected Record changes, Bill of Material (BOM), onsite planning yard engineering support during installation to answer liaison action record (LARs), and other engineering services depending on the planning yard. DSA costs are generally funded up to one year prior to planned installation due to drawing development lead time and installation preparation efforts. These costs are ship specific since drawings are developed for each ship, not class of ship.   - FY19 includes DSA costs in the amount of $60K in support of LHA-7 installation planned in FY20. - FY20 installations include one (1) LHA-6 Class ship at $90K.

Description.val:
OPNAVINST 3400.10G articulates U.S. Navy Chemical, Biological and Radiological Defense (CBRD) policy and establishes functional responsibilities to ensure the highest level of the Fleet readiness and warfighting sustainability in a CBR environment. JBAIDS systems will identify and quantify biological organisms of operational concern and other pathogens of clinical significance for confirmatory and prognostic purposes. The CENTCOM HR urgent need (dated Aug 2009) modifies the JBAIDS ORD (dated May 2003) with the addition of detection capability for the 2009/A/H1N1 influenza. The equipment procurement is funded out of the Joint Service CBDP Budget P-1 Item Nomenclature: JBAIDS. Beginning in FY13, system will install with refrigeration unit.

[JBAIDS] Remarks: A total of twenty two (22) completed of twenty three (23) planned. The LHA 7 installation will occur during PSA in FY20. LHA 8 has successfully added JBAIDS to the baseline and should have the system installed during construction. DSA costs for FY19 were recently added to support LHA 7 installation.

Title.val: CW001 CHEMICAL WARFARE PROGRAM JBPDS BLK 1

Name.@footnote: The procurement costs are specifically referring to installation and Design Service Allocation (DSA) costs as there are no equipment procurement costs with any detector system installed. DSA costs are for government engineering oversight/support in preparation for ship installation and ship class planning yards for engineering services which include ship check, development and approval of ship installation drawings (SIDs), Ship Selected Record changes, Bill of Material (BOM), onsite planning yard engineering support during installation to answer liaison action record (LARs), and other engineering services depending on the planning yard. DSA costs are generally funded up to one year prior to planned installation due to drawing development lead time and installation preparation efforts. These costs are ship specific since drawings are developed for each ship, not class of ship, excluding JBPDS for DDG Class ships which are class-wide drawings.  - FY21 costs are for DSA only in the amount of $220K in support of planned removal of JBPDS from LCS 1 thru LCS-4 in FY22.

Description.val:
OPNAVINST 3400.10F articulates U.S. Navy CBRD policy and establishes functional responsibilities to ensure the highest level of Fleet Readiness and warfighting sustainability in a CBR environment. JBPDS BLK I provides for improved biological agent detection and reporting. The JBPDS ORD (J2-B001-Revision 1, dated 7 January, 2002) validates the modification. The equipment procurement is funded out of the Joint CBDP Budget P-1 Item Nomenclature: (JP0100) JBPDS.

[JBPDS BLK 1] Remarks: A total of 74 completed of 78 planned. JBPDS on LCS-2 and LCS-4 were previously planned to be relocated to function properly in FY21 since both hulls has JBPDS partially installed by the ship builder during construction and are inoperable. These hulls were recently changed to training assets. At the concurrence of OPNAV and USFFC, the systems will now be removed permanently onboard LCS-2 and LCS-4 vice relocated. LCS-1 and LCS-3 were recently changed to training assets. At the concurrence of OPNAV and USFFC, the systems are now to be removed from LCS-1 and LCS-3 and reallocated for new ship construction.

Name.@footnote: There are no equipment procurement costs with any detector system installed. The Design Service Allocation (DSA) costs are for government engineering oversight/support in preparation for ship installation and ship class planning yards for engineering services which include ship check, development and approval of ship installation drawings (SIDs), Ship Selected Record changes, Bill of Material (BOM), onsite planning yard engineering support during installation to answer liaison action record (LARs), and other engineering services depending on the planning yard. DSA costs are generally funded up to one year prior to planned installation due to drawing development lead time and installation preparation efforts. These costs are ship specific since drawings are developed for each ship, not class of ship.

Description.val:
OPNAVINST 3400.10G articulates U.S. Navy Chemical, Biological and Radiological Defense (CBRD) policy and establishes functional responsibilities to ensure the highest level of the Fleet readiness and warfighting sustainability in a CBR environment. The Next Generation Chemical Detector (NGCD) provides shipboard point detection system for detecting and identifying nerve and blister agent contamination presence. The equipment procurement is funded out of the Joint Service Chemical Biological Defense Program Budget.

[NGCD] Remarks: The Next Generation Chemical Detector (NGCD) is a technology replacement for the IPDS and IPDS-LR systems. The program consists of four variants for multiple applications; the Navy will be installing variant 1 for fixed chemical agent detection capability. The inventory objective for shipboard installations is 183. Previously, installations were expected to start in FY22 with advance planning activities (DSA) to start in FY21, but recent Joint program delays now expect NGCD fielding to Navy to commence FY22, necessitating Navy change planned installations to start FY23.

Title.val: CW001 CHEMICAL WARFARE PROGRAM IPDS-LR HEATER UPGRADE

Name.@footnote: IPDS-LR Heater Upgrade plan - The procurement costs are specifically referring to Installation and Design Service Allocation (DSA) costs as there are no equipment procurement costs with any detector system installed. DSA costs are for government engineering oversight/support in preparation for ship installation and ship class planning yards for engineering services which include ship check, development and approval of ship installation drawings (SIDs), Ship Selected Record changes, Bill of Material (BOM), onsite planning yard engineering support during installation to answer liaison action record (LARs), and other engineering services depending on the planning yard. DSA costs are generally funded up to one year prior to planned installation due to drawing development lead time and installation preparation efforts. These costs are ship specific since drawings are developed for each ship, not class of ship.  - FY19 funding includes $430K for DSA costs.  - FY20 funded installations total twenty-four(24). Costs include twenty four (24) DDG-51 Class ships.  - FY21 funded installations total forty-two (42). Costs include three (3) LHD-1 Class at $34K each, four (4) CVN-68 Class ships at $34K each, and thirty-five (35) DDG-51 class ships at $33K each.  Total FY21 installation costs is $1,393K plus $248K in DSAs.

Description.val:
OPNAVINST 3400.10G articulates U.S. Navy CBRD policy and establishes functional responsibilities to ensure the highest level of the Fleet readiness and warfighting sustainability in a CBR environment. CBRD Improved Point Detection System Heater Upgrade (IPDS-LR HU) provides the ability for IPDS-LR to function in various extreme environmental conditions that may cause system degradation and ultimately failure. This is a new, emergent requirement to ensure automated chemical agent detection is operationally available. The equipment development and procurement for this upgrade is funded out of the Joint Service CBDP Budget and is expected to be provided to Navy by early FY19. Navy must fund integration and installation. DSA costs are expected to start early FY19 with installations to start in FY19.

[IPDS-LR Heater] Remarks: Seventy-Seven (77) heater upgrades are currently planned and budgeted. The Joint Service CBDP is procuring seventy (70) heater upgrade kits vice eighty-nine (89) previously expected. Some of the heater upgrade kits are expected to be able to be split and installed on two ships vice one, increasing planned kit installation from seventy (70) hulls to seventy-seven (77) hulls. Upgrade kits are now expected to be provided to the Navy by the end of first quarter FY20 vice during FY19, shifting planned installation start to 3rd quarter FY20. A contract to produce the heater upgrade kit was awarded by the Joint Service CBDP February 2019. Once heater upgrade is fully developed by the Joint Service CBDP, further refinement of integration and installation costs can be accomplished and inventory objective may be adjusted.

Title.val: CW001 CHEMICAL WARFARE PROGRAM DRSKO STOWAGE

Name.@footnote: Dismounted Reconnaissance Sets, Kits, and Outfits (DRSKO) Stowage plan - The procurement costs are specifically referring to Installation and Design Service Allocation (DSA) costs as there are no equipment procurement costs with any detector system installed. DSA costs are for government engineering oversight/support in preparation for ship installation and ship class planning yards for engineering services which include ship check, development and approval of ship installation drawings (SIDs), Ship Selected Record changes, Bill of Material (BOM), onsite planning yard engineering support during installation to answer liaison action record (LARs), and other engineering services depending on the planning yard. DSA costs are generally funded up to one year prior to planned installation due to drawing development lead time and installation preparation efforts. These costs are ship specific since drawings are developed for each ship, not class of ship.   - FY18 funded installation includes one (1) DDG-51 Class at $141.2K to occur Q4 FY19.   - FY19 funding includes DSAs in the amount of $160K for LSD-41 class.  - FY20 installations includes one (1) LSD-41 Class ship at $150K, one (1) CG-47 Class ship at $150K, and one (1) LPD-17 class at $150K.  Total install cost is $450K.
Name.val: 1.1.1) CW001 CHEMICAL WARFARE PROGRAM DRSKO STOWAGE - NonOrganic

ImplementationMethodName.val: [none specified]:: Installation Name: CW001 CHEMICAL WARFARE PROGRAM DRSKO STOWAGE

Description.val:
OPNAVINST 3400.10G articulates U.S. Navy Chemical, Biological and Radiological Defense (CBRD) policy and establishes functional responsibilities to ensure the highest level of the Fleet readiness and warfighting sustainability in a CBR environment. Chemical Biological Radiological Nuclear Dismounted Reconnaissance Sets, Kits, and Outfits (CBRN DRSKO) provides Navy Boarding Teams personnel protection from current and emerging CBRN hazards through detection, identification, sample collection, decontamination, marking, and hazard reporting for CBRN threats.  Due to system size and storage requirements of equipment and materials, a ship alteration must be accomplished for adequate shelving, electrical power, ventilation, and stowage space security. The equipment procurement is funded out of the Joint Service Chemical Biological Defense Program Budget.

[CW001 CHEMICAL WARFARE PROGRAM DRSKO STOWAGE] Remarks:  A total of four (4) installations are currently planned.  One (1) for each of the following ship classes: DDG-51, LPD-17, LSD-41, and CG-47.  This alteration will install shelving and provide controlled access to support proper stowage of the Joint developed CBRN DRSKO system.  DDG class SIDs were previously developed and approved.  SIDs for the other three (3) classes are being developed to support FY20 installations. The planned installation for DDG-66 was delayed from Q4 FY18 since the SCD was not fully approved. The SCD is now fully approved. The installation was scheduled to start  fourth quarter FY19, but the installation team was required to wait on the ship to offload ammunition due to required hotwork. The installation started December 2019 and is expected to complete January 2020.  The installation for LPD and CG class ships shifted from FY19 to FY20 to align funding to expected SCD approval and ship schedule. SIDs are currently being developed to support SCD approval.

ModificationTitle.val: CW001 CHEMICAL WARFARE PROGRAM EMBD UPGRADE KIT

Title.val: CW001 CHEMICAL WARFARE PROGRAM EMBD UPGRADE KIT

Name.val: 1.1.1) CW001 CHEMICAL WARFARE PROGRAM EMBD UPGRADE KIT - NonOrganic

ImplementationMethodName.val: [none specified]:: Installation Name: CW001 CHEMICAL WARFARE PROGRAM EMBD UPGRADE KIT

Description.val:
[CW001 CHEMICAL WARFARE PROGRAM EMBD UPGRADE KIT] Remarks: EMBD is a new acquisition program, which will provide lifecycle replacement kits for existing JBPDS system installations. The EMBD kit is intended to install within the existing JBPDS frame, reducing overall installation complexity and refurbishment unit costs. Labor for refurbishment of ships already equipped with the JBPDS system will be funded by the Joint Service Chemical Biological Program, however, the Navy must fund DSA and other incidental costs, to include planning yard and ship yard costs, to complete planned back-fit upgrades. The Navy now expects to receive sufficient quantities of the upgrade kit by FY21 to start installations late FY21 vice previously planned FY23. DSA costs will now start to be incurred in FY20 to support FY21 installations.

- FY20 costs include DSAs in the amount of $96K.

- FY21 installations include three (3) DDG-51 Class ships at $25K each. Total installation costs are $75K plus $527K in DSAs.
